content.description: Campus start or kick a foot under the roof. Pick whichever holds you want low on the little face. Do 2 or 3 moves to easy topout. Good gym to cragger. Landing is a bit funky and pinched but not bad.
content.location: When you first emerge from the corridor and bend right to walk across top of a boulder, the problem below you is the V2. The little archway just down is this problem.

content.description: Together with Finders Keepers, these are perhaps the best two king lines in Southwestern PA. Stand start begins standing with both hands in the seam, just to the left of the dihedral that is Finders Keepers. Climb straight up the seam, trend slightly left, and then once you hit the rail, traverse all the way right to top out in the corner. This problem is just as, if not more exhilarating than it's sister king line to the right. A bit safer now that the landing is a bit smoother, but still quite tall and scary. Not for the feint of heart. The sit start to this problem is one of the best undone lines in SWPA. Start all the way down in the pit on rock that can be slightly damp. Do a long move out the roof and onto some of the best stone in SWPA--these holds are the feet of the stand start. Move through a very shouldery crux that is perhaps V12 on it's own, so a long v12 into a highball v10...V13 altogether?
content.location: Stand start in the seem. Just to left of Finders Keepers.

content.description: A very techy, highball slab when it's clean. With more traffic this should become a classic. Left arete may be V5. Right arete V3?
content.location: Down in the Pit!

content.description: Tricky, balancy slab that requires some delicate footwork. Feels impossible until it doesn't.
content.protection: Pads--there's a tree trunk that's a bit tricky and the pads slide. Helpful to have someone hold a pad up even. (See beta photo). A slightly tricky landing.
content.location: On the boulder opposite the boulder with all the king lines, on the slab to the right of the V0 arete.

content.description: Start as low as you can and trend right and up.
content.location: When you first exit the corridor into the boulders, and start walking across a boulder, this is the problem just below on that boulder.

content.description: Start on the left side of the slabs and traverse right on the glorious underclings with good feet. Or go the other way. Great for beginners because nice easy but slightly technical climbing, very low to the ground.
content.location: Warmup slabs

content.description: Climbs out the same route as Pridelands, about 10 feet left. This has another name.
content.location: Climbs out the same route as Pridelands, about 10 feet left.

content.description: Nice easy slabs on great stone. Gets a little high but the climbing is secure.
content.location: The slabs all the way left.

content.description: Just a fantastic little easy arete that follows a seem on amazing stone. Three variations: a) layback leaning left (best), b) layback leaning right, c) straight on jamming. Do each version a hundred times they're all fun.
content.location: Just to the left of Feast of the Feet.

content.description: Nice little arete that climbs nicely when clean.
content.location: Down in the pit.

content.description: The excellent (slightly harder?) sister to Astral Travelin'...just as committing and maybe just as good!
content.location: Start on the obvious jug at the seam on the left arete, left of Astral Travelin'. Climb using the arete left handed and a couple edges on the face for right. Same finish for the last couple moves as Astral Travelin'.

content.description: If you're standing on the slab that looks down on Wide Awake Nightmare, look down to your left. That's it. Starts off a little ledge.
content.location: If you're standing on the slab that looks down on Wide Awake Nightmare, look down to your left. That's it. Starts off a little ledge.The line to the right is a little harder and a little more dangerous, and can be started from down around the corner.

content.description: Start under a roof on the right side. Do a couple stout moves out the roof on slightly lower quality rock to hit the lip. Do a stout mantle up on to the primo rock.
content.location: Located on the backside of the same boulder as Wide Awake Nightmare and Founding Fathers. This is the overhanging roof you'll see off to the right when you first enter the Proving Grounds. Problem starts on the far right side of this roof. There is another Chaz Ott problem that starts more in the middle of this roof that is also about V9.

content.description: This isn't the name. Someone tell us what the name is. In the pit. Looking at the tall unclimbed blank face, it's on the right (left if you're looking down into the pit). Starts under the little overhang and continues up the nice edges on the face in the corner.
content.location: This isn't the name. Someone tell us what the name is. In the pit. Looking at the tall unclimbed blank face, it's on the right (left if you're looking down into the pit). Starts under the little overhang and continues up the nice edges on the face in the corner.

content.description: Layback or jam this off-hands crack. As with the line to the left, easiest just to drop off, though if you trend way right and traverse the lip around the corner, you can get to a good foot ledge over there that makes topping out easier.
content.location: Obvious hand crack far right on the face backside of warmup slabs.

content.description: On the warm-up slab, climb up the crack, using one of the three variations (left layback, right layback, or straight jamming), then walk the ridge on top, downclimb, traverse right across the good horseshoe hold and down into the underclings, repeat ad nauseum.
content.location: Warm up slabs

content.description:
Sit start laying back the wide crack. Continue up to a small roof using the corner and right face. From below the roof begin worming your way up and into the squeeze chimney. Continue squeezing your way to the top! 

 The down climb for this route is the same as for the other problems on this spectacular block. This is an excellent and very secure feeling squeeze chimney. Once you are inside the chimney, chances falling out are very slim.
content.location: This is the obvious wide chimney to the left of the Somnambulist arete. There is a bolted line between Jacey Cakes and Somnambulist.

content.description: Great clean line. Fairly stout for V5...maybe v6? Sit start awkwardly for a difficult balancy first move or two.
content.protection: Get creative with the padding here. It starts in a pit and the falls can be awkward. Not terrible if you have enough pads.
content.location: This is on the same boulder as Wide Awake Nightmare and Finders Keepers, just to the right and up from these. Starts in a little pit.

content.description: Bouldering for trad climbers. Stick your fist in that crack. Then stick your other fist in that crack until there's no more crack to stick your fist in.
content.location: Immediately left of Dangerous Waters. The line immediately left is currently (probably) a pretty cool project and seems about V9 with the crux being not dabbing on Dangerous Waters.

content.description: Ultra classic dihedral. Doesn't get any better than this. Originally went at V10 with a terrifying all points off, out of control dyno to the lip. New beta has unlocked a slightly more controlled sequence. With enough pads and the new beta, this problem can now be done relatively safely, but still very, very exhilarating. If you're tall with reach, you should be able to static and it will feel v8ish. If you're shorter and can't static, you may be double-clutching to the left lip, which is still quite scary, and you definitely get v9 points if you do it htat way. Has been done by a 5'5" climber this way. Hero.
content.location: Start low with right hand on the far right of the right face, and left hand on a left-facing sidepull a couple feet right of the dihedral (hands about shoulder length apart). Do a thrutchy left toss into the seam in the dihedral and continue up, climbing both sides of dihedral. And alternate start is to just start as low in the dihedral as you can, but this eliminates the challenging first move coming in from the right, which is the full value line.

content.description: The slab immediately right of Founding Fathers. Technical little line that's nice to climb up, but also serves as the downclimb for everything on this boulder. For the downclimb, it's nice to have a pad on the boulder at the bottom. Once you get close the the bottom, grabbing the left arete is handy for the final bit.
content.location: The slab immediately right of Founding Fathers. Technical little line that's nice to climb up, but also serves as the downclimb for everything on this boulder. For the downclimb, it's nice to have a pad on the boulder at the bottom. Once you get close the the bottom, grabbing the left arete is handy for the final bit.

content.description: Start matched on the edge on left side of face, and either campus or throw a foot under the roof or do some heel hooking to deadpoint up to arete. Transition around right side of arete and topout.
content.protection: Pads--landing is a bit tricky but easy to pad if you have enough.
content.location: The arete on the boulder just down from the warm-up boulder. The top out is onto the slab looking down at Wide Awake Nightmare.

content.description: Start under a low roof on a horizontal flake feature. Climb onto the face using crimps and a pocket, to a slopey gaston flake just below the lip. Top out with horizontal hand jams and underclings up and to the right.
content.location: This starts under the butt dragging low roof just to the right of the off hands crack.

content.description: Finest V8R in SWPA. Mega, committing, sustained. Anchors are accessible with a long (18ft) stick. TR recommended (just TRing this thing is great--you could be happy never bouldering it, especially since bouldering it carries serious injury potential). Grade is v8/.13b. This might be a little soft in the grade, but be very, very careful if you're going ground up. The route stays with you to the very top, and even after the jug at the lip, you have a couple technical moves heading left around the arete, followed by some easy climbing over dicey death blocks.
content.location: The incredible sheer, steep face around the corner left from Wide Awake Nightmare. Start down in the bottom pit right, matched on a little edge close to right arete. Climb through a little bouldery section  to the good horizontal, then trend right through incut flakes, then back left through right-facing flake a flat jug. Continue left toward arete and up to incut jug at lip, then around left using hidden holds or handjams to stance. Be very careful for the final VB topout, which is on dicey death blocks. Clear the zone below.Undone variation 1: don't go into right facing flake, instead, trend right and direct up, using right arete as necessary (V10?)Undone variation 2: Once you hit the 2/3 height flat jug, do a big move right to a similar flat jug, then go up direct with a huge deadpoint over the lip. Very committing. (V9?)The arete into crack in between Wide Awake and Astral Travelin' (using left hand on arete and right hand into seam) is a hard, sketchy project.

content.description: A good one to get the fingers warm for the kinglines. Unfortunately the topout (either left or right) is pretty gamey, so most folks just climb to the high break and then do a slightly tricky down climb back down the problem. If you do decide to top out, it's slabby beached whale nightmare to the right of the protrusion, or exposed arete horn wrapping nightmare exit left.
content.location: Backside of the warmups, immediately around the corner right from Vlad.

content.description: A small but highly concentrated area, containing quite possibly the best stone and highest quality hard king lines in Southwestern Pennsylvania (or honestly the state, but....we're partial). Home to the notable highball boulder problems Finders Keepers and Wide Awake Nightmare, the very committing mega highball Astral Travelin', as well as a number of stunning double digit projects. There are also a couple high quality V0-1 problems, and a few excellent lines in the v5-6 range (Vlad and Founding Fathers), as well as a few other decent moderate lines in the v2-v4 range--enough to keep easy- to moderate- climbers interested for a day or so, but probably not much beyond that. There are about 8 short, stout sport routes, also, generally of average quality, with the exception of one stunning bolted line that would be v14-ish if you didn't need a rope (but you do). Because the terrain at the rocks is quite rough and the boulders are concentrated, there isn't a lot of room to move around, and the main zone probably can't handle more than 10 or so people at a time. Apart from the main zone, there is a) the corridor as you walk in, with perhaps 7-10 moderate but lower quality problems, the deep Pit below the main stuff holding another 5 or so problems, and some more average quality lines down below in the forest to the left (opposite direction from the Pit), which can help folks spread out. If the parking is crowded, consider going back down the road to the Pyle, a.k.a. Falls City Pub boulders. The Proving Grounds is heavily hunted at times (and there is a tree stand on the hike out). Wear orange/consider going elsewhere during hunting season--the first day of hunting season in particular typically sees about 15 hunters out and about. Rattlesnakes have been spotted on top of the boulders along the ridgeline, but not, to our knowledge, down among the boulders or on top of the established problems. Use caution.
